Award.AwardTitle: Optical Lattice Systems as a Laboratory for Quantum-Classical Crossover
Award.AbstractNarration:
Presently optical-lattice systems holding ultracold-temperature atoms may already be tuned experimentally so that they may behave either classically or quantum mechanically. In this work such systems are studied theoretically. For instance, it will be shown that the very act of monitoring the atoms may cause them to behave classically. The goal is to turn such observations into quantitative methods to analyze and engineer nanoscale devices that operate at the crossover between quantum mechanics and classical mechanics.

Research topics from this work are incorporated into both graduate and undergraduate courses and specialist scientists are trained, so that the project will contribute to the development of high-technology workforce. Scientifically, the project should help to build the basis for future nanotechnology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project was about theoretical physics of atoms illuminated by light.

First, we studied two-atom systems in an optical lattice. The original motivation was the peculiar experimentally verified fact that the atoms may form a bound molecule even if they repel each other.  We have developed a methodology to analyze such dimers, and described their properties in detail. Second, we have analyzed light scattering from a low-temperature gas, Bose-Einstein condensate, in an atom trap that has two sides.  The atoms may move between the sides of the trap, and light is used to monitor how many of the atoms are on each side.  We have solved this problem both quantum mechanically, and also in a classical-physics approximation we had developed. The surprise here is that the classical approximation works even if there are only ten atoms, at which point one would reasonably assume that the system should already belong to the domain of quantum mechanics. Third, we have simulated propagation of light in a dense low-temperature gas sample by regarding each atom as a small radiator that reacts to incoming light by sending out scattered light of its own. It turns out that all atoms may respond to the incoming light cooperatively as one system, and the optical properties of the gas may be quite different from what the standard textbooks have said for a hundred years.

Foreseeable applications include algorithms that replace costly or intractable quantum mechanical computations with much less demanding classical methods. Also, the cooperative response of cold gases is likely to become an issue when one attempts to optimize the quantum mechanical nature of the coupling of atoms and light by resorting to denser atomic gases, say, in applications to quantum information and precision measurements. Potential applications notwithstanding, we wish to generate new theoretical concepts. Our work is pure basic research, and the long-term goal is to help build the science basis for future quantum technologies.  In the interim, the broad benefits to society come from training of workforce capable of organized and innovative approaches to quantitative problems in general. Three students supported in part by this grant graduated with Ph.D. degrees during the project period.
